website_content.content:
FACT CHECK: video shows Mike Pence did not get hit by a water balloon
===============
No, Mike Pence did not get hit by a water balloon thrown by a young girl in Iowa
================================================================================
!
Presidential , despite what video on Twitter might otherwise suggest, did not get hit in the back of the head by a water balloon, and definitely not by a young girl sporting a howitzer for an arm.
On Friday, the former Vice President sat down for an interview with Tucker Carlson at the  in Des Moines, Iowa. Pence and Carlson  that included voting machines, the Jan. 6 insurrection and military aid to Ukraine — in which the crowd booed him at one point.
**Mike Pence after Jan. 6 indictment:**
If only that were the end to Pence's troubles.
A video uploaded to social media later that same afternoon went viral, showing Pence purportedly getting struck by a water balloon as he marched in a parade.
Problem is, it's not Mike Pence in the video. It was Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman who took a well-tossed water balloon to the back of his cranium during a Fourth of July parade in Stewart Manor, NY.
"The water balloons and soaker guns  at the Stewart Manor parade," Blakeman said on Facebook, adding that he had fun during the annual event. The girl who threw the balloon at him with such ferocity, Blakeman joked, has a possible future career with the New York Yankees or Mets.
The young girl's well-timed shot was part of last week's festivities in New York, according to Blakeman's video. Unless Pence was sweating buckets through his interview Friday with Carlson, he remains dry in Iowa.
**Summer concerts:**
© 2024 www.indystar.com. All rights reserved.

While it has a reasonable reputation for journalistic integrity, it can sometimes focus on sensational stories. Its ability to fact-check and contextualize events is decent, but it does not have the extensive resources of larger nationals.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence directly addresses the claim by confirming that the video does not show Mike Pence being hit with a water balloon but instead Bruce Blakeman. The fact check thoroughly explains the context of the incident and provides credible information clarifying the misconception.

website_content.content:
Screenshots from a viral video showing a girl hitting a politician in the head with a water balloon
Video supposedly showing former vice president Mike Pence getting hit in the head with a water balloon has gone viral. Some people have even said the girl in the video should receive the Cy Young Award, given each year to the best pitchers in Major League Baseball. But that’s not Pence getting hit.
The video has over 1.2 million views on Twitter alone and has been shared by sports sites like SBNation. But if you take a closer look at the man who gets knocked in the head, it’s not the former vice president.
Who is the unfortunate soul getting clocked with a water balloon? It’s Nassau County executive Bruce Blakeman who was taking part in a Fourth of July parade in New York where people with thousands of water balloons lined the streets.
The water balloons at the parade on Long Island are all in good fun and Blakeman himself even shared the video on Facebook with the caption, “The New York Yankees and New York Mets could certainly use her!”
There are plenty of images and videos with fake content going viral recently, including a Truth Social post where Donald Trump seems to call his Republican presidential opponent a virgin; a video where a man on an American Airlines flight said he saw a Reptilian creature wink at him; and an image where Ron DeSantis appears to give a rather awkward quote in his high school yearbook. But they’re all fake.
Even a viral story about boating deaths in Alabama spread far and wide this week, claiming...[Content truncated]

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Video shows girl hitting Mike Pence in the

website_content.content:
The claim: Video shows girl hitting Mike Pence in the head with a water balloon
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A July 14 Instagram video (, ) shows a man with white hair being struck in the head with a water balloon while walking in a parade.
"Girl Hits Former Vice President Mike Pence In The Head With A Water Balloon," reads the video's on-screen text.
The post garnered more than 60,000 likes in four days. A similar Instagram video received more than 70,000 likes in three days before it was deleted. Other versions of the claim have been shared on , ,  and .
**Follow us on Facebook!**
Our rating: False
-----------------
The video shows Nassau County, New York, official Bruce Blakeman getting hit by the balloon at a Fourth of July parade, not former Vice President Mike Pence. Pence was walking in a parade in a different state at the time.
Video shows different man, not Pence
------------------------------------
The video was originally   on July 12 by Blakeman, the Nassau County executive, who joked in both captions that the New York Yankees and Mets should scout the girl.
In a comment under the Facebook post, Blakeman said the video was filmed at the Stewart Manor parade, where water balloons and soaker guns are a long-standing tradition.
"Please do not be offended," Blakeman said in the comment. "All those who march including me, do so at their peril and are fair game. I had fun even if I got a little wet!"
**Fact check:**
Thousands of people lined the streets, many with coolers full of water balloons, at the Long Island parade, according to  Blakeman linked beneath the Facebook post.
Meanwhile, the former vice president attended a Fourth of July parade in Urbandale, Iowa,  reported.
USA TODAY reached out to the user who shared the post for comment but did not immediately receive a response.
The claim has also been debunked by , ,  and .
Our fact-check sources:
-----------------------
*   Bruce Blakeman, July 12, 
*   Bruce Blakeman, July 12, 
*   CBS, July 4, 
*   Des Moines Register, July 5, 
_Thank you for supporting our journalism. You can ._
_Our fact-check work is supported in part by a grant from Facebook._
]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: USA Today is a national newspaper that provides broad coverage of news, including politics. While it maintains good journalistic practices, its tendency towards sensational headlines can affect its reliability.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence clearly confirms that the video features Bruce Blakeman being hit by a water balloon rather than Mike Pence. It thoroughly explains the setting and the nature of the event, making it very relevant in determining the truthfulness of the claim.

metatags.og:description: Social media users are claiming a viral video shows a girl hurling a water balloon at Mike Pence's head as he marches down a street. This is false; the clip shows a local politician -- not the former US vice president -- getting hit during a July 4 parade in the state of New York, which includes a water balloon fight as part of the tradition.

website_content.content:
Choisir votre langue
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Any commercial use of this content requires a subscription. Click here to find out more.
"Give this girl the cy young for hitting mike pence in the melon with a water balloon," says a July 14, 2023 tweet sharing the video, referring to the award given to Major League Baseball's best pitchers.
Similar posts claiming the clip shows a girl pelting Pence above the shoulders racked up millions of views across Twitter, Facebook, TikTok and other social media platforms. US sports media brands The Sporting News and SB Nation amplified the rumor.
"This girl was built for the NFL. She lasers a perfect lead throw on the noggin of former Vice President Mike Pence with a water balloon," The Sporting News said in a since-deleted tweet.
 
 
But despite the claims taking off online, the video does not show Pence, who is seeking the presidency in 2024 after serving in the White House as Donald Trump's vice president.
A Pence spokesperson confirmed to AFP that the former vice president is not the person who was struck by the balloon, pointing to Twitter Community Notes appended to one post to debunk it.
The footage actually shows Bruce Blakeman, the county executive of Nassau County, New York. Blakeman, a Republican, posted the video to Twitter and Facebook (archived here and here) on July 12, joking that the New York Yankees and the New York Mets, the state's two professional baseball teams, could both use the girl on their squads.
"The water balloons and soaker guns are a long tradition at the Stewart Manor parade," Blakeman wrote in a comment under his Facebook post. "Please do not be offended. All those...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: AFP Fact Check specializes in debunking misinformation with reliable sources and empirical data, making it highly trustworthy, especially in the context of viral media.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides a clear statement that refutes the claim by confirming that the individual hit was Bruce Blakeman, alongside providing commentary from Pence’s spokesperson. This strengthens the accuracy regarding the identity of the person involved in the video.

Filed under:
*   
Girl goes Cy Young and obliterates Mike Pence’s head with water balloon
=======================================================================
WHAT A THROW!
By  Jul 14, 2023, 4:30pm EDT
Share this story
----------------
*   
*   
*   
*   
### **Share** All sharing options for: Girl goes Cy Young and obliterates Mike Pence’s head with water balloon
*   
*   
*   
*   
Children are our future.
> give this girl the cy young for hitting mike pence in the melon with a water balloon 
> 
> — belt sanderson (@avoidthehanoid) 
This all seems fair. It appears this march, or parade, or whatever was intended to be a water event because dozens of balloons are being thrown onto the street. I just don’t think Mike Pence thought he’d be clocked in the dome by a fastball like this.
Seriously, this takes a lot of skill. It’s surprisingly difficult to throw a water balloon with this much force AND accuracy at the same time. Grip too hard and it’ll pop in your hand, too loose and you’re getting no velocity. Also this was far from a gimme throw and she absolutely nailed it.
The adults around her seemed clearly in support of it. You can hear a man say “go,” clearly helping her line up the shot — before gleefully yelling “YOU GOT HIM IN THE HEAD!”
What an absolute champion. Keep an eye on her, MLB — because a future’s contract might be around the corner.

No, Mike Pence Was Not Hit in the Head By a Water Balloon Thrown By a Young Girl
===============

No, Mike Pence Was Not Hit in the Head By a Water Balloon Thrown By a Young Girl
================================================================================
#### By  | Jul 14, 2023
!
!!
On Friday, a video went viral that purportedly showed former vice president Mike Pence being hit in the head by a water balloon during a parade. That balloon was hurled by a young girl with an absolute cannon. While that would be pretty funny, unfortunately we have to report the story isn't true.
Here's the video everyone is talking about:
It certainly looks like it could be Pence but, it is not. Instead, the target is the man who posted the video, Bruce Blakeman, who is the Nassau County executive. The video comes from the annual Stewart Manor 4th of July parade on Long Island. Longstanding tradition has it that local firemen, officials and families in the village have a big water balloon fight towards the end of the parade. This girl's toss was part of that.
Let's be real, that girl has an absolute howitzer for an arm.  and  teams need to be flocking to that town to scout her. But, not, she didn't hit the current GOP presidential candidate. Pence was not in Long Island on the 4th, instead .
For some reason, that rumor began to spread on Friday:
While it might be a better story if it was true, it isn't. We hate to break up everyone's fun.
We did love this analysis from Rob Friedman, though:
Flawless execution from Pitching Ninja.
/

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... game Tuesday against the Tampa Bay Rays.
Why, you ask?
  4]
In a viral video, 10-year-old Alexa Cardona is seen hitting Nassau County executive Bruce Blakeman in the back of the head with a water balloon during a Fourth of July parade. Twitter
> The  and  could certainly use her! 
> 
> — Bruce Blakeman (@NassauExec) 
The fifth grader went viral for a video of her drilling Nassau County executive Bruce Blakeman in the back of a head with a water balloon during a Fourth of July parade.
The video took off on social media when it was incorrectly suggested that the politician was former vice president Mike Pence.
 is a staple of the annual Stewart Manor parade, with more than 2,000 projectiles prepped for this year’s celebration.
Video of the incident went viral, and with good reason, as Cardona plunked Blakeman from 100 feet away.
  4]
Yankees outfielder Harrison Bader is impressed with the video of Alexa Cardona hitting Bruce Blakeman in the back of the head with a water balloon. Fox News screen grab
  4]
Alexa Cardona watched Yankees batting practice Tuesday. Fox News screen grab
Both attended batting practice Tuesday and had a chance to meet several Yankees, who 
Outfielder Harrison Bader had been wondering who it was that tossed the balloon: “That was you? Good throw …. very impressive.”
Cardona told Bader she learned to throw like that by playing softball.
  4]
Alexa Cardona and Nassau County executive Bruce Blakeman attended Tuesday’s Yankees-Rays game. Fox News screen grab
Hitting coach Sean Casey had a good laugh over the video: “Are you serious? Is that your arm? That’s actually a good throw. We could use you. Can you sink it? Cut it a little bit?”
Rookie shortstop Anthony Volpe also chuckled after seeing the clip: “That’s pretty good.”
While Cardona and Blakeman enjoyed the pregame festivities, they didn’t have much to talk about after the game, which  leaving them in last place in the American League East and 3 1/2 games back in the wild card standings.

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The New York Post is known for its tabloid-style journalism with sensational headlines. Its accuracy can be questioned due to a history of less stringent fact-checking and occasional bias.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides further detail about the girl who threw the balloon and her subsequent recognition by the Yankees. However, it only indirectly addresses the claim about Mike Pence and does not directly clarify the misconception present in the video.
